citation.article-title: Fervidobacterium riparium sp. nov., a thermophilic anaerobic cellulolytic bacterium isolated from a hot spring
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Fervidobacterium riparium sp. nov.
Fervidobacterium riparium (ri.pa′ri.um. L. neut. adj. riparium that frequents the banks of rivers).
Cells are motile and occur singly, in pairs and in chains of up to 17 cells in one chain.
Thermophile, grows at temperatures of 46–80 °C, with optimum growth at 65 °C.
Moderate alkaliphile, grows at pH 5.7–9.0, with optimum growth at pH 7.8.

Obligate organotroph, ferments peptone, yeast extract, pyruvate, sucrose, glucose, cellobiose, starch, xylan, microcrystalline cellulose (Avicel), CMC, amorphous cellulose, filter paper and birch sawdust.
Glycerol, arabinose, lactose, pectin, dextran and chitin do not support growth.
The main products of glucose fermentation are H2 and acetate.
Elemental sulfur stimulates growth and is reduced by hydrogen, released during the course of fermentation.
Sulfate, thiosulfate and nitrate do not influence growth, but sulfite inhibits it.
The type strain is 1445tT ( = DSM 21630T = VKM B-2549T), isolated from a hot spring of ‘Goryachiy Plyazh’ (hot beach) region, Kunashir, Kuril Islands, Russia.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 31 mol%.
